head.title: Lowly Lightning Closes Out Sweep of Even Lowlier Isles

hedline.hl1: Lowly Lightning Closes Out Sweep of Even Lowlier Isles

block.p: It was a memorable day for Tommy Salo, the 24-year-old goaltender making his National Hockey League debut, but for all the wrong reasons.
He missed the team bus back to the hotel after a midday practice, then missed the boat tonight as he and the Islanders were beaten, 5-2, by the Tampa Bay Lightning before 18,922 at the ThunderDome.
It was a memorable day for Tommy Salo, the 24-year-old goaltender making his National Hockey League debut, but for all the wrong reasons.
He missed the team bus back to the hotel after a midday practice, then missed the boat tonight as he and the Islanders were beaten, 5-2, by the Tampa Bay Lightning before 18,922 at the ThunderDome.

Three Lightning goals came in a 5-minute-31-second stretch of the second period, and that proved good enough to drop New York to 11-21-5 and reduce its playoff hopes with 11 games left to virtually zero.
The victory sealed a 4-0 Tampa Bay sweep of the Islanders this season. The Lightning's only other season sweep has been against hapless Ottawa.
"They've gotten some timely goals against us and they've had outstanding goaltending," said Islander Coach Lorne Henning, referring to Daren Puppa, who stopped 29 shots.

Henning had a five-minute, closed-door meeting with his team afterward. "We've been shooting ourselves in the foot," he said. "It's not that we're being outhustled. We're making mental mistakes. Like turnovers in the middle."
Left wing Rob Zamuner gave Tampa Bay a lead 2:25 into the second period with a straight-on 12-footer in traffic. Salo's view was blocked by teammate Paul Stanton on the shot.
Next, John Tucker sneaked an ice-hugging 25-footer under Salo on a power play. Henning viewed that as the only weak goal Salo gave up.
And then came the backbreaker, a short-handed goal by Zamuner.
It was the fifth time in five games that New York has given up a goal while on a power play. Astonishingly, in their last 37 power-play opportunities, the Islanders have been outscored, 7-4.
"I know it's not pretty," Henning said.

A little later in the period, the game was held up for 12 minutes as the teams brawled. After it, the Islanders were given a five-minute power play, mainly because Tampa Bay's Enrico Ciccone registered 22 minutes in penalties.
New York finally got a goal 6:38 into the final period, courtesy of right wing Zigmund Palffy. But it couldn't keep this from being among the Islanders' more forgettable performances. SLAP SHOTS

TOMMY SALO, who helped Sweden win a gold medal at the 1992 Olympics, was recalled from Denver last Wednesday. He rejected 29 shots Tuesday night. . . . Center KIRK MULLER, also making his Islander debut after arriving in a trade with Montreal, had an active though non-scoring game. . . . Left wing BRETT LINDROS was scratched after suffering back spasms during the day. . . . Defenseman RICH PILON, out since March 5 with a sprained left ankle, is expected back either Friday or Sunday. Defenseman SCOTT LACHANCE, who suffered a broken left ankle Feb. 28, figures to be activated within a week. HOCKEY
